ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Force analysis on many different types of structures, supports, and beams including torques, displacements, stresses/strains, bending, and deformation. Helped solidify how to visualize and analyze everyday structures and how to optimize them as well.
I learned to analyze mechanical systems and learned many new concepts like mechanical stress and strain.
I learned fundamental concepts that apply to the real world pertaining to materials and forces.
I gained fairly comprehensive basic mechanical engineering knowledge.
we learned how to solve for various reactions and internal forces.
I learned more about how larger mechanical systems work in terms of statics and inner mechanics.
I developed a very solid foundation in most all of the topics we covered. I now feel very good about how to approach statics problems.
mech e skills
I learned how to calculate the response of various types of mechanical systems and bodies in response to forces in many situations
I learned how to solve a variety of static system problems. This course gave a fundamental overview of a variety of problems, such as trusses, beams, simple machines, and more.
Learnt all about statics and beams was a great   course.
analysis of internal and external forces of static systems, especially beams

In the first part of the semester, we analyzed forces and moments in bodies at equilibrium, and we spent a lot of time on truss analysis. With the exception of trusses, much of this first part felt like a review of earlier physics classes, with a lot of FBDs.
In the second part of the semester, we learned about deformation, including stress-strain diagrams; deformation due to axial loads, torsion, bending, and shear loads; wide-flange beams; deflection of beams; and buckling of columns.

This course built upon PHYS180. I learned to use force and moment equilibrium equations to solve problems. I learned about the method of joints and method of sections. I learned how to solve for internal forces and use that information to pick materials.
Developed skills in statics and deformation analysis.
Learned the basics of statics specifically related to internal forces and moments.

I learned how to draw a free-body diagram and evaluate forces, stresses, strains, and other properties of physical systems.

This was a very difficult class for me. I expected it to be the same difficulty level as PHYS 180, which I took last semester, but for whatever reason it was significantly more challenging for me.
Really learn how to do applied physics, and build on simple calculations throughout the semester

This was the first time I've really started to learn about stress and strain concepts on bodies. This is actually very useful in the work I'm doing in clubs now, where we need to design a combustion chamber capable of enduring high thermal / pressure stresses.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Lectures were clear and informative, tests felt reflective of the material on the problem sets. 
Weaknesses: a lot of problems in the problem sets rely on information from the textbook, outside of lecture notes, which made it hard to determine what would be tested in exams. Lectures were very occasionally a bit disorganized, it was also sometimes hard to hear the professor.
Strengths: Well organized to facilitate learning and the course follows a good progression.
This course is very straightforward and well taught.

This course was extremely strong. Dr. Qiu's lectures were clearly laid-out and taught, and her notes (which she posted for the class) were a fantastic resource. The course environment was cordial. I found all of the policies to be fair and not stress-inducing.
professor wasnt great, content kind of boring

Instruction for this course was well-paced. We spent many more weeks going through the first few units than the last few but spending more time on the foundational concepts was helpful in increasing mastery before progressing to more difficult concepts.  The problem sets provided a variety of example problems to help students understand the material. 

The course could be improved if more example problems were provided to help students prepare for exams. While exam review questions were provided, they were limited in quantity. Additional problems would allow students more focused practice and may lead to more effective preparation than students searching for problems in the text themselves. 

Additionally, if the solutions to the midterm exams were posted on CANVAS, students would be able to use these to prepare for the final exam.
The course was well taught, though it was unavoidable that the material could get a bit dry.

This course covered a lot of useful material, and I felt that I gained a good understanding of each unit. However, there was not much of a synthesis of concepts, where we used multiple concepts all together. This will probably come in future courses though.

Strengths
Thorough, well organized 
Weaknesses

Could have had more representative examples in class.

strengths: highly organized, approachable professor, heavily textbook based so it's easy to get help and extra practice problems

weaknesses/improvements: lectures could be more interactive

Strengths: The course was well-organized, and it followed the textbook closely, so I could reference the textbook for anything I didn't fully understand in class. The problem sets and exams all felt very fair. 
Weaknesses: There was one assignment where we had to go out and find a real truss to analyze, I wish that there had been more assignments like that. That being said, many of the problem set questions did indicate the applications of what we were learning, so it didn't feel too abstract.

Professor Qiu is great. Her lectures stick to the point and are pretty clear. The workload is totally manageable. If you need help with the material, you have to be proactive and ask for it, but help is available if you ask. I think the course could be improved with more office hours.
The course moves in a very linear and straightforward way but it could tie in more theoretical background and real world applications.

Outside of lecture, the course was very well made. The lecture itself was not helpful in my learning of the material, I found it much easier to just read the book to understand these topics. I think if the lecture was better organized, skipped or went faster through unimportant details, and gave us reasons as to why/what we are doing in each chapter it would have been better.
The course was at 9am. I missed many, many lectures. This is my fault. That said, the course could be improved by video-recorded lectures.
The psets were very good for practice since it gave you harder problems to work with than you would see on an exam

Strengths: Teacher is very kind, I actually love the textbook (I read every relevant chapter), hw hits a perfect balance to challenge us while not being overwhelming

Weaknesses: Recorded lectures, please implement this for future students. The classroom we were in was set up with the equipment to do it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's a prerequisite for the mechanical engineering major but otherwise, it's not a bad class to take up if you're curious or interested about structures and the forces on them and the effects of forces (loads, torques, displacements, bending). The workload is about standard for a mechanical engineering class (kinda heavy).

If you're on the fence about being MechE, a more practical class might do better to convince you. But except 185, the practical classes are all higher level... 

It is a good class though.
It is a solid class in terms of engineering and applied sciences, however it is not necessarily a "fun" class.
For those that it is not required for, no. I did not feel it helped me greatly beyond strictly mechanical engineering principles
Yes, Professor Qiu is a good lecturer, and the material is interesting.
Yes, the course will be helpful for anyone who is interested in mechanics.

If you would like a background in statics or just enjoy solving the types of problems in the subject (such as those with free body diagrams, identification of forces, application of equations, etc.), I would recommend this course. I needed a background in statics and also enjoy the puzzle-like quality of statics problems, and I really enjoyed this course.
if you need it
Sure, but be careful about drawing out free-body diagrams and equations, they'll take points off harshly otherwise. Do that and you'll be fine.

I would recommend this course to increase your understanding of the basics of mechanical engineering calculations. That being said, if you are not majoring in mechanical engineering, there isn't much reason to take this course unless you are very interested in learning how to calculate the effects of forces on mechanical systems.

This course was very interesting and provided a good fundamental understanding of concepts for future studies in the engineering degree. MENG 280 is a required course for all mechanical engineering majors, but it is still a good course to take even if it were not required for the degree.
Yes it's good for teaching statics even if it is a bit hard at times.
yes, it is a good overview of engineering mechanics/statics
Yes, if you liked PHYS180. Professor Qiu is very nice and willing to help students. The workload is manageable and the grading is fair.
This is the kind of course you really only take as a major requirement but it is a relatively straightforward engineering class.
This course was very interesting if you like the applications of physics. Most problem set questions were interesting, both challenging and fair.

I would recommend  this course if you it is a requirement for your major, or if you really enjoy physics and are willing to do the work. The class is challenging, but the workload is manageable and material is learnable
Yes, really good class. Eye-opening to understand how structures around us are set up to endure various forces, etc.
